ID Notes: Distinguished from C.edule and P. exiguuum by internal crenulations extending through shell, distinguised from pavicardium by 2 x posterior lateral teeth. Called C. lamarkii in Tibble
Key Ref: Tebble, N. (1966). British bivalve seashells. A handbook for identification. Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History); Hayward, P. J., & Ryland, J. S. (Eds.). (2017). Handbook of the marine fauna of North-West Europe. Oxford University Press.; Marine Bivalve Shells of the British Isles online key (https://naturalhistory.museumwales.ac.uk/BritishBivalves/key.php)

Key Ref: Novana database (https://odaforalle.au.dk/); Tebble (1966); Marine Bivalve Shells of the British Isles online key (https://naturalhistory.museumwales.ac.uk/BritishBivalves/key.php)

ID Notes: Based on location data and Hayward Key to family, composed of Tateidea spp. (Potamopyrgus antipodarum), Hydrobia spp. (Hydrobia ulvae, Hydrobia ventrosa), and Rissoa spp. (Rissoa membranacea). Samples likely include a combination, but cannot distinguish families. (resolves to http://species-identification.org/species.php?species_group=mollusca&selected=beschrijving&menuentry=soorten&record=Ventrosia%20ventrosa on online key)
Key to Crangonidae, species confirmed based on location
Key to Palaemonidae, could be P. adspersus and P. elegans based on location

Larger individuals appear to be Gammaridae family (gnathopods similar size, 2 slightly larger in some, urosome segments with spines, larger eye), Smaller individuals cannot be distinguished based on family,
Key Ref: Lincoln, R. J. (1979). British marine amphipoda: Gammaridea (Vol. 818). British Museum (Natural History).

ID Notes: Separated idotea and non-idotea; idotea may be mix of balthica and chelipes;
11x non-idotea individuals appear to be Jaera albifrons, 2x C. carinata, samples not analysed due to insufficient biomass
All common species in region are Podocoida order
Includes both Chirononmidae and Ceratopogonidae
Only two individuals, samples not analysed due to insufficient biomass

Meets description for A. marina, as the most common ploychaete taxa, analysed separately
